Award.AwardTitle: Directed Nanoparticle Assemblies in Thin Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

To generate nanoparticle (NP)-based functional devices that capitalize on the unique characteristics of NPs, it is mandatory to control the macroscopic ordering and orientation of the NP assemblies and the inter-particle ordering with high precision in thin films. Block copolymer (BCP)-based supramolecules provides unique opportunities to address this challenge. The influence of small molecule loading, NP loading, film thickness, interfacial interactions, solvent fields and sample treatments on the thermodynamics and kinetics of hierarchical assemblies in thin films of the NP/BCP-based supramolecule blends will be systematically studied. Approaches will also be developed to tailor the ordering of the small molecules within the BCP microdomains so as to achieve control over inter-particle ordering. The proposed study will transform our existing knowledge of the hierarchical assembly of hybrid materials and enable one to capitalize on the unique properties of the numerous off-shelf NPs.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The proposed studies will lead to a foundation in understanding the fundamental principles underpinning the hierarchical assembly of multicomponent composite systems, establishing a framework and protocols for the fabrication of nanocomposite materials that will transform approaches for device fabrication in the renewable energy, microelectronics and storage industries.

The PI will continue to devote herself to mentoring students and promoting public awareness of materials science. She will take advantage of her prior outreach experiences and expertise and will collaborate closely with existing on-campus outreach programs and local organizations to educate the next generation of material scientist. Her outreach efforts include developing laboratory modules to strengthen two polymer courses initiated by the PI; expanding her existing efforts for career mentoring of postdoctoral fellows and senior graduate students; and promoting polymer science among the younger generation through research opportunities and seminars at local high schools.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Controlled assemblies of nanoparticles and organic building blocks clearly hold the promise to overcome the incompatibility in the processing techniques and to enrich the functionalities of organic/inorganic nanocomposites using different elements on the periodic table. Thin films of nanocomposites where nanoparticles are hierarchically structured with single particle precision can exhibit new properties unseen in either nanoparticle or polymer alone. To this end, it is important to develop fundamental understanding in their phase behavior and identify critical parameters that govern the thermodynamic of nanocomposite in thin films. Equally important is to systematically understand the kinetic pathway of the assembly process to develop fabrication process compatible with existing nanomanufacturing infrastructure. During the funding period, we made advances in several fronts. We demonstrated that lamellar and cylindrical supramolecular nanocomposites can form ordered layered structures in thin films. The nanoparticle spatial arrangements within the film can be controlled in 1-, 2- and 3-D with very high precision. These studies allow one to manipulate inter-particle distance and electronic/optical coupling, a foundation to harness new property of these new materials. Our studies also showed that the entropic contribution is fairly significant and dictates the phase behavior of nanocomposites containing nanoparticles of different sizes. This, in turn, can be used to manipulate inter-particle coupling between nanoparticles of different chemical composition. Furthermore, we investigate how the processing condition, specifically solvent annealing condition on the nanocomposite phase behavior and identify one single parameter that governs the assembly kinetics and kinetic pathway. These studies built a foundation to further explore new materials and to engineering properties unseen in existing materials. Various new media have highlighted our work. The PI was invited to discuss our studies in KPFT 90.1 Pacifica Radio Houston.  

 

Broader impact:

We developed 3 more lab modules for the undergraduate course, MSE151 titled “Introduction to polymeric materials” at University of California, Berkeley. The lab modules were offered to the class of 40-50 students. For each lab session, there are 5-6 students to ensure hands on experience and close interactions with their TA. The feedbacks from students are extremely positive. These modules will be used as base to develop laboratory component for the freshman course E45, which serves over 150 students each year. We consistently offer research opportunities to undergraduate through campus outreach programs and local high school students from Oakland CA.  We continue our partnership with a high school in Oakland and give seminars to students and recruit interns.


Last Modified: 01/06/2015
Modified by: Ting Xu
